Fig. 9 Fig. 10 In-situ DRIFTS of NH3 adsorption on Mn-100 (a), Mn-140 (b) and Mn-180 (c) at different temperatures. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 In situ DRIFTS of NO + O2 adsorption on (a) Mn-100, (b) Mn-140 and (c) Mn-180 at different temperatures. State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing 100029 China MnOx catalysts with 3D structure (Mn-HT) were prepared by the hard-template method using KIT-6 as a template, and the catalytic performance for the selective catalytic reduction of NOx by NH3 (NH3-SCR) at low temperatures was investigated. The template KIT-6 prepared by the different hydrothermal temperatures can exert significant effect on the catalytic performance of Mn-HT catalysts. Among the Mn-HT catalyst, the catalyst prepared using the template obtained at the hydrothermal temperature of 140 °C (Mn-140) exhibited the highest catalytic performance. Characterizations showed that Mn-140 catalyst possesses high reducibility with abundant surface oxygen species and Mn4+ species. NH3-TPD and in situ DRIFTS demonstrated that there are more Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites on the surface of Mn-140 catalyst, both of which would promote the adsorption and activation of NH3, leading to the reduction of NOx efficiently to proceed mainly by the Eley-Rideal(E-R) mechanism, accompanied by the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Nitrogen oxides NH3-SCR MnOx Reaction mechanism Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The massive emission of nitrogen oxide (NOx) from stationary sources and mobile sources can cause serious environmental problems [1–4]. The high concentration of NOx in atmosphere will not only cause acid rain, ozone depletion and photochemical smog, but also lead to a series of health problems [5,6]. With the rapid development of economy and the improvement of people’s living standards, the regulations for the NOx emissions have become more and more stringent. Thus, the NOx emission needs to be controlled urgently. Among the different technologies for the control of NOx, selective catalytic reduction of NOx by NH3 (NH3-SCR) has been proved to be an efficient and reliable way [7,8]. V2O5/TiO2 promoted by WO3 or MoO3 catalyst is widely used for the removal of NOx from stationary sources [8–11]. However, this catalyst is usually placed before the dust-extraction unit due to the requirement of the high operating temperature (300–400 °C). In order to reduce the negative influence of dust on the catalytic performance of the NH3-SCR catalyst to prolong its lifetime, one effective way is to place NH3-SCR unit after the precipitator and desulfurizer. In this case, the temperature is low (< 200 °C) and the development of highly active low-temperature NH3-SCR catalyst is desirable [12]. Considerable efforts have been devoted to developing active low-temperature NH3-SCR catalysts, such as metal-ion exchanged molecular sieves and Mn-based catalysts [13–15]. Among these catalysts, Mn-based catalysts have attracted much attention for their good redox properties and environmental friendliness [14,15]. The de-NOx performance of MnOx catalyst can be influenced by many factors [16]. The crystallinity of MnOx is closely related to the preparation methods and calcination treatment [17]. The amorphous MnOx prepared by solid phase reaction (SP) and co-precipitation (CP) methods exhibited higher activity in comparison with the highly crystallized MnOx prepared by citric acid (CA) method, due to the amorphous phase promoted proton insertion and releasing, resulting in more active sites for the reaction. In addition, the activity of MnOx catalyst is also influenced by the catalyst structure [6]. Tian et al. [18] compared the de-NOx performance over different morphology of MnO2 nanotubes, nanorods and nanoparticles, and found that MnO2 nanorods showed the highest de-NOx efficiency (above 90%) at temperature of 250–300 °C due to its high NH3 adsorption ability. Recently, we found that the porous MOF-derived MnOx catalyst showed high activity due to crystalline defects and abundant acid sites [19]. The hard-template method for preparing catalyst can effectively obtain well-developed mesoporous material with high specific surface area [20,21]. KIT-6 is a nanomaterial with 3D symmetrical ordered mesoporous structure, which can be as a template to prepare catalysts with the similar structure by hard-template method [22]. The 3D structure with larger specific surface area and well-developed pore structure is more conducive to the formation of active sites for the NH3-SCR reaction [5]. Hence, the MnOx catalyst with 3D structure prepared using KIT-6 as a template has great potential for NH3-SCR. To date, little research on 3D MnOx NH3-SCR catalyst prepared by hard-template using KIT-6 has been reported. Therefore, a deep understanding about the application of the 3D MnOx catalysts in NH3-SCR has not been obtained yet. In this study, a novel 3D MnOx catalyst with different pore size and mesoporous structure was prepared by hard-template method using KIT-6 as the template, and its catalytic performance for the low-temperature NH3-SCR of NOx has been investigated. The physical and chemical properties of the prepared catalysts were characterized by the X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption, Raman, hydrogen temperature -programmed reduction (H2-TPR), temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The reaction mechanism of NH3-SCR over Mn-HT catalyst was also revealed by In-situ DRIFTs. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation MnOx catalyst was prepared by the hard-template method. First, the KIT-6 template was synthesized according to the method described previously [22]. Three different KIT-6 were obtained by varying the hydrothermal temperature (100, 140 and 180 °C). A proper amount of Mn(CH3COO)2·4 H2O and KIT-6 obtained at different hydrothermal temperatures were dissolved in 20 mL ethanol, the mixture was stirred at room temperature until the dry powder was obtained. The powder was dried at 100 °C for 12 h. The impregnation procedure was repeated, followed by drying and calcinating at 300 °C for 4 h in air. The resulting sample was treated with 1 M NaOH to remove the silica template. Afterwards, the sample was centrifuged, washed several times with deionized water to neutral, and then dried at 100 °C overnight to obtain MnOx catalyst (Mn-HT). MnOx prepared using the different KIT-6 obtained at the hydrothermal temperature of 100, 140 and 180 °C are denoted as Mn-100, Mn-140 and Mn-180, respectively. The Mn-D catalyst was also prepared by direct decomposition of Mn(CH3COO)2·4 H2O at 300 °C for 4 h in air. 2.2 Catalyst characterization XRD patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE system with Cu Kα radiation. The diffraction patterns were collected from 10° to 80° at a rate of 10 °/min. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and the pore size distributions were measured using Quantachrome Nova Automated Gas Sorption System. The specific surface area was calculated by the BET equation and the pore size was derived from the desorption branch of the isotherms by BJH method. The Raman measurement was performed using micro-Raman spectroscopy (Renisaw, InVia) under the 532 nm−1 excitation laser light. XPS was carried on the electron spectrometer (VG Scientific, ESCALab220i-XL) with Mg Kα radiation, in which C 1 s signal (284.8 eV) was used as the reference. H2-TPR and NH3-TPD were conducted on a Micrometrics ChemiSorb 2720 analyzer, and recorded continuously by TCD detector. The sample was first pretreated in N2 flow at 300 °C for 1 h, then cooled down to room temperature. Subsequently, H2-TPR was carried out by heating the sample at a rate of 10 °C·min−1 in 10% H2/N2 flow (50 mL min−1). For NH3-TPD, the temperature was raised to 750 °C at a rate of 10 °C·min−1 in N2 flow after the catalyst was saturated by NH3/N2 flow at 100 °C. In-situ DRIFTS was recorded on a Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer. The sample was first pretreated in N2 flow at 300 °C for 1 h, then take the background spectrum at the desired temperature. The sample spectrum was obtained by subtracting the corresponding background spectrum. The feeding gas concentration is as follows: 500 ppm NH3 or 500 ppm NO and 5% O2. For the NH3 (or NO + O2) adsorption, the catalyst was exposed to a flow of NH3 (or NO + O2) for 1 h at each temperature, then the spectra were taken. For the transient studies, the sample was first pre-exposure to a flow of NH3 (or NO + O2) for 1 h at 125 °C, then purged with N2 for 30 min, followed by switching to NO + O2 (or NH3) to record the dynamic changes of the spectra. 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluation The catalytic performance was tested in a fixed-bed quartz reactor with 0.12 g catalyst. The reaction gas consists of 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 5% O2, 5% H2O (when used), and N2 balance. The gas flow rate is 300 cm3·min−1, corresponding to the gaseous hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 140,000 h−1. The concentrations of the effluent gases were analyzed online by chemiluminescence NO/NO2 analyzer (Thermo Scientific, model 42i-HL) and a FITR spectrometer (Gasmet FTIR DX4000). The NOx conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated as follows: NO x conversion= NO x in - NO x out [NO x ] in × 100 % N 2 selectivity = NO x in + NH 3 in - NO x out - NH 3 out - 2 N 2 O out NO x in - NO x out + NH 3 in - NH 3 out × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic NH3-SCR performance The NH3-SCR activities of the Mn-HT catalysts were tested and shown in Fig. 1(a). It can be seen that the catalytic activity is decreased in the order of Mn-140 > Mn-100 > Mn-180, and Mn-140 catalyst showed the best catalytic activity in the whole test temperature range, especially below 200 °C. Over Mn-140 catalyst, more than 90% NOx conversion can be achieved between 100 and 200 °C, and the maximum conversion reached 98% at 125 °C. Evidently, the activities of Mn-100 and Mn-180 catalysts were much lower than that of Mn-140 catalyst, and Mn-180 is the least active one, over which the maximum NOx conversion was only 73%. As illustrated in Fig. S1. The NH3-SCR activity of Mn-D catalyst is much lower than those of Mn-100 and Mn-140 catalysts in the temperature range of 75–250 °C. It indicated that the Mn-HT catalyst prepared by the hard template method is superior to the Mn-D catalyst prepared by the traditional method. The N2 selectivities of Mn-HT catalysts were shown in Fig. 1(b), which follows the order of Mn-140 > Mn-100 > Mn-180, and the N2 selectivity was decreased with the increase of temperature, similar to the previous report [19,23]. With increasing temperature, more N2O would be produced by the reaction between NO and activated NH3 species, thus leading to the decreased N2 selectivity [24–26]. Mn-140 catalyst showed the highest N2 selectivity, and more than 82% N2 selectivity can be obtained in the temperature range of 75–200 °C. This comparison suggests that the preparation temperature of the template KIT-6 significantly affects the NH3-SCR catalytic performance of the Mn-HT catalysts. In the practical application, the existence of H2O cannot be excluded. Therefore, the NH3-SCR activity was also tested in the presence of 5% H2O. As shown in Fig. 2, the activities of Mn-HT catalysts are just slightly decreased in the presence of H2O. The inhibition of H2O could be due to the competitive adsorption between H2O and the reactants [27,28]. This indicated that Mn-HT catalysts exhibited high tolerance to H2O, which is very important for the practical application. Fig. 3 shows the Arrhenius plots for the conversion rate of NOx over Mn-HT catalysts. The apparent activation energies (Ea) for Mn-100, Mn-140 and Mn-180 catalysts are 14.6, 16.0 and 16.6 kJ/mol, respectively. The activation energy is similar, however, the preexponential factor (A) of the three catalysts are significantly different. The preexponential factor follows the order of Mn-140 (A= 39,535) > Mn-100 (A=8646) > Mn-180 (A=3729), which is consistent with the catalytic performance order. This fact indicates that over Mn-140 catalyst there are much more active sites than those of Mn-100 and Mn-180 catalysts [19]. Therefore, Mn-140 catalyst exhibited the highest NH3-SCR activity. 3.2 XRD, N2 adsorption and Raman analysis The low-angle and wide-angle XRD patterns of the Mn-HT catalysts are shown in Fig. 4. As illustrated in Fig. 4(a), an obvious diffraction peak at 2θ = 0.97°, which corresponds to the {211} plane, can be observed over all the Mn-HT catalysts. This demonstrates that Mn-HT catalysts are of the ordered mesoporous structure, which successfully replicates the cubic Ia3d structure of KIT-6 [20]. As shown in Fig. 4(b), the peaks assigned to the crystalline phase of MnO2 (28.88°) (PDF#50–0866) and Mn3O4 (18.00°, 31.02°, 32.32°, 36.09°, 36.45° and 37.98°) (PDF#24–0734) appeared over Mn-100, Mn-140 and Mn-180 catalysts [29,30]. From the intensity of the XRD peaks and full width at half maximum, the Mn-140 catalyst is of the smallest crystal size and the lowest crystallinity compared with the other two Mn-HT catalysts. As reported previously [22,31], the hydrothermal temperature of preparing KIT-6 would affect its mesoporous pore size. The appropriate pore size of corresponding KIT-6 could be obtained as the hydrothermal temperature is 140 °C. The appropriate pore structure could promote the dispersion of Mn precursor in the pores and contribute to its reconstruction during the calcination process, thus resulting in the smallest crystallite size formed. The smallest crystallite makes Mn-140 catalyst possess the most active sites. The N2 adsorption-desorption test was performed over the Mn-HT catalysts. Fig. 5(a) is the N2 isotherm adsorption-desorption curves. Based on the IUPAC classification, the curves showed type IV isotherms with H2 hysteresis loop [32], showing that the prepared Mn-HT catalyst possessed ordered mesoporous structure, which is consistent with the result of low-angle XRD. The textural properties are shown in Table 1. Obviously, the BET specific surface areas of Mn-100, Mn-140 and Mn-180 were 169, 180 and 171 m2/g, respectively. This result showed that the Mn-HT catalysts possessed large surface areas, which is due to the successful anti-replication of the ordered mesoporous structure from KIT-6 template. The large specific surface area of Mn-HT catalysts would be beneficial to the NH3-SCR reaction [5,14,33]. Previous reports also proposed that the large specific surface area would contribute to the NH3-SCR activity of MnOx [17,19,34], and the reported surface areas are 51, 72, and 96 m2/g, which are much lower than those in this study. The pore size and pore volume of the Mn-HT catalysts increase with increasing the hydrothermal temperature of KIT-6 template. The suitable pore size can increase the possibility and efficiency of the collision between reactant molecules and active sites over the Mn-HT catalysts, and can facilitate the diffusion and migration of the product molecules in the pore structure, thus promoting the SCR reaction [35,36]. Raman analysis is also conducted to further understand the nature of the manganese species of the Mn-HT catalyst. As exhibited in Fig. 6, there is a distinct characteristic band at 650 cm−1, which can be attributed to the characteristic of Mn-O (A1 g) lattice vibrations of Mn3O4 [14,32]. The band intensity of Mn-140 catalyst is the weakest, indicating that manganese oxide is of low crystallinity, which is consistent with the result of XRD. 3.3 XPS analysis The surface composition and the chemical state of the elements on the surface of the Mn-HT catalysts were studied by XPS. Fig. 7(a) exhibits the Mn 2p XPS spectra of Mn-HT catalysts, two main peaks centered at about 642.0 and 653.0 eV are observed, which are attributed to Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2, respectively. The two typical characteristic peaks could be deconvoluted into six peaks: the peaks centered at ∼640.9 and 652.1 eV, 642.2 and 653.8 eV, 644.2 and 655.9 eV correspond to the Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+ species, respectively [14,37,38]. According to the XPS analysis, the ratio of Mn4+/Mn over Mn-140 catalyst is higher than those of Mn-100 and Mn-180 catalysts (as shown in Fig. 7(a)). It has been reported that the NH3-SCR activity of Mn oxides decreased in the order of MnO2 > Mn5O8 > Mn2O3 > Mn3O4 > MnO [18], Mn4+ species and their redox process are responsible for the high activity of the NH3-SCR reaction at low temperature [33]. Besides, abundant Mn4+ would promote the oxidation of NO to NO2 [14,39], which was favorable for the NH3-SCR reaction to proceed. Thus, the higher concentration of Mn4+ would play a vital role in the high low-temperature de-NOx activity of Mn-140 catalyst. For O1s spectra (see Fig. 7(b)), the XPS peaks at around 529.9 eV and 531.3 eV are corresponding to the lattice oxygen (Oβ) and surface oxygen (Oα), respectively [40,41]. As shown in Fig. 7(b), the Oα/(Oα + Oβ) ratio of Mn-140 catalyst is remarkably higher than those of the other two Mn-HT catalysts. It is generally recognized that the Oα species exhibits higher activity than Oβ due to its high mobility [14]. More Oα would also contribute to the oxidation of NO to NO2, which is beneficial to the SCR reaction on the catalyst. As discussed in the XRD analysis, the decrease of the crystallization of MnOx can inhibit the diffusion of Mnn+ and O2- ions and result in abundant Mn4+ and surface oxygen (Oα) on the catalyst surface [12]. As shown in Fig. S2, the highest conversion of NO to NO2 was obtained over Mn-140 catalyst, indicating that Mn-140 catalyst possessed the highest NO oxidation ability. Combined with the above analysis, the highest contents of Mn4+ and Oα over Mn − 140 are both beneficial to the oxidation of NO to NO2, and further improve the catalytic activity through the “Fast-SCR” pathway [42,43]. 3.4 H2-TPR It is well known that the reduction behavior of the catalyst is an important factor influencing the NH3-SCR activity [1]. Fig. 8 shows the H2-TPR profiles of Mn-HT catalysts. It can be seen that the Mn-HT catalysts exhibited two reduction peaks at about 246–282 °C and 475 °C, which are mainly attributed to the stepwise reduction of MnO2 to Mn3O4, and Mn3O4 to MnO, respectively [42,44–46]. Compared with Mn-100 and Mn-180 catalysts, the former peak over Mn-140 catalyst evidently shifted to lower temperature and the peak intensity is also higher. This indicates more Mn4+ existed over Mn-140 and it possessed higher redox property and oxygen mobility, which is consistent with the XPS analysis, and would be beneficial to improving the catalytic performance for low-temperature NH3-SCR reaction [14,47,48]. Furthermore, the area of the reduction peak is positively correlated with the consumed amount of H2. It could be seen that Mn-140 exhibited the largest H2 consumption among three catalysts, indicating that more reducible species were exposed over Mn-140, which might result from its 3D ordered mesoporous structure with large surface area [49]. 3.5 NH3-TPD The adsorption and activation of NH3 on the active sites of the catalyst surface play a key role in the NH3-SCR reaction [1]. Therefore, the surface acid amount and strength of the Mn-HT catalysts were evaluated by NH3-TPD, the corresponding profiles of the three catalysts are depicted in Fig. 9(a). From Fig. 9(a), the NH3 desorption profiles of Mn-100 and Mn-140 present three distinct desorption processes from 100° to 750°C due to the adsorbed NH3 species with different thermal stability. The desorption peak below 200 °C is assigned to weak acid sites, while the desorption peak above 600 °C is associated with strong acid sites, and the peak at about 400 °C could be related to medium acid sites [19,50]. Different from the Mn-100 and Mn-140, the Mn-180 only displays two desorption peaks ascribed to the weak and medium acid sites, lack of the peak of strong acid sites. In addition, we found that the desorption peak of Mn-140 was shifted to the high temperature region, suggesting the presence of stronger acid sites. The normalized desorbed NH3 of the catalysts was calculated, as shown in Fig. 9(b), the total amount of the acid sites over Mn-140 is remarkably higher than those on the other two catalysts. The higher amount of acid sites could be attributed to its ordered 3D mesoporous structure with large specific surface area, which contributes to the adsorption and activation of NH3. 3.6 In situ DRIFTS study 3.6.1 NH3-adsorption In-situ DRIFTS of NH3 adsorption on Mn-HT catalysts was carried out, and the corresponding results are displayed in Fig. 10. Over both Mn-100 and Mn-140 catalysts, four bands at about 1608, 1454, 1402 and 1258 cm−1 can be observed. The bands located at ∼ 1608 and 1258 cm−1 are correlated to NH3 coordinated to Lewis (L) acid sites [14,42], while the bands at 1446 and 1402 cm−1 can be ascribed to the NH4 + species on Brønsted (B) acid sites [51,52]. It is obvious that the intensities of NH3 adsorption bands on the Mn-140 catalyst are significantly stronger than those on the Mn-100 catalyst, indicating that the total amount of the B acid and L acid sites over Mn-140 catalyst is apparently higher than that of Mn-100, as also confirmed by NH3-TPD results. During the heating process, the band intensity of L acid weakens with the increase of temperature, but it is still strong even at 250 °C. Whereas over Mn-180 catalyst, it showed extremely weak peaks at 1256 (L acid), 1402 (B acid) and 1608 (L acid) cm−1, which indicates that there are very few acid sites on its surface. With the increase of temperature, the peaks signal gradually weakens and disappears at 200 °C. More L and B acid sites over Mn-140 catalyst would contribute to the adsorption and activation of NH3, thus leading to the high activity for the low-temperature NH3-SCR reaction. 3.6.2 Adsorption of NO + O2 Fig. 11 exhibited the in-situ DRIFTS of NO + O2 adsorption on the Mn-HT catalysts at different temperatures. Over Mn-100 and Mn-140 catalysts, it can be seen two bands located at about 1300 and 1500 cm−1, which are attributed to monodentate nitrate and bidentate nitrate, respectively [53–56]. The intensities of those two bands increased as the temperature increased from 100 to 150 °C. While further increasing the temperature from 150 to 250°C, the two bands were weakened but not disappeared, which was due to the desorption/decomposition/transformation during the heating process. It is noted that the intensities of the peaks over Mn-140 are weaker than those over Mn-100. Over Mn-180 catalyst, the bands are different from the Mn-100 and Mn-140 catalysts, which are located at about 1358 cm−1 (monodentate nitrate), 1422 cm−1 (trans-N2O2 2−), and 1630 cm−1 (bridging nitrate) [54,57]. It is well known that there is competitive adsorption occurred between nitrate species and gaseous NH3 [58]. Therefore, the weak adsorption of NOx over Mn-140 catalyst can leave more active sites available for the adsorption of NH3, which is a key step in the NH3-SCR of NOx [1,7]. 3.6.3 Reactivity of adsorbed species In situ DRIFT spectra changes as a function of time in NH3 flow over Mn-140 catalyst after pre-exposure to NO + O2 at 125 °C are shown in Fig. 12(a). After adsorption of NO + O2, the monodentate nitrate (1300 cm−1) and bidentate nitrate (1475 cm−1) are appeared [53,59]. As the flow was switched from NO + O2 to NH3, the intensities of the peaks assigned to monodentate nitrate and bidentate nitrate just decreased slightly, indicating that NH3-SCR reaction could occur following the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism over Mn-140 catalyst. The reactivity of adsorbed NH3 over Mn-140 catalyst was further studied and the results are shown in Fig. 12(b). After adsorbing NH3, three bands attributed to the N-H stretching modes of coordinated NH3 to L acid sites (1246 and 1608 cm−1), and the NH4 + species on B acid sites (1402 cm−1) are observed [42,51,52]. Upon subsequently switching to NO + O2, the bands ascribed to adsorbed NH3 species decreased quickly and disappeared in 5 min, indicating both the adsorbed NH3 on L and B acid sites are reactive species. As the time prolonged, the peaks assigned to monodentate nitrate (1300 and 1377 cm−1) and bidentate nitrate (1475 cm−1) appeared [53,54]. Therefore, NH3-SCR of NOx over Mn-140 mainly proceeds following the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism, accompanied by the L-H mechanism [15]. As described above, Mn-140 catalyst possessed the most active sites among the three MnOx catalysts. Moreover, less NOx species with low activity were adsorbed over Mn-140 catalyst, thus leaving more active sites for the adsorption of highly reactive NH3 species (see Fig. 10). Consequently, Mn-140 exhibited the highest low-temperature activity for the reduction of NOx by NH3. 4 Conclusions A novel MnOx catalyst with 3D structure and mesoporous structure has been successfully fabricated. The Mn-140 catalyst showed superior low-temperature NH3-SCR activity, over which more than 90% NOx conversion and 82% N2 selectivity were achieved between 100 and 200 °C. The ordered mesoporous structure with appropriate pore size and large specific surface area contributed to the high redox property and high contents of surface oxygen species, Mn4+ active species and acid sites, which resulted in its excellent catalytic activity. Besides, the reaction pathway on the Mn-140 catalyst is proved to be dominated by the E-R mechanism, accompanied by the L-H mechanism. This work provides new insights into the effect of 3D structure with different pore size on catalyst performance and new idea for designing low-temperature NH3-SCR catalyst. coredata.dc:description: MnOx catalysts with 3D structure (Mn-HT) were prepared by the hard-template method using KIT-6 as a template, and the catalytic performance for the selective catalytic reduction of NOx by NH3 (NH3-SCR) at low temperatures was investigated. The template KIT-6 prepared by the different hydrothermal temperatures can exert significant effect on the catalytic performance of Mn-HT catalysts. Among the Mn-HT catalyst, the catalyst prepared using the template obtained at the hydrothermal temperature of 140 °C (Mn-140) exhibited the highest catalytic performance. Characterizations showed that Mn-140 catalyst possesses high reducibility with abundant surface oxygen species and Mn4+ species. NH3-TPD and in situ DRIFTS demonstrated that there are more Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites on the surface of Mn-140 catalyst, both of which would promote the adsorption and activation of NH3, leading to the reduction of NOx efficiently to proceed mainly by the Eley-Rideal(E-R) mechanism, accompanied by the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism.
coredata.dc:title: Highly ordered mesoporous MnOx catalyst for the NH3-SCR of NOx at low temperatures
